[ (Sheikh Ali Salman, told, BBC)
(Sheikh Ali Salman, said, for national dialogue to be meaningful, the government had to show its willingness to offer 'concrete solutions')
(Crown Prince Salman al-Khalifa, seen as, a reformist)

(al-Wefaq leader, acknowledged, many young protesters had lost faith in the main opposition parties)
(Sheikh Salman, believed that the only way forward was to work with reformists within the Sunni Muslim royal family, including the US- and UK-educated Crown Prince Salman, )
(Sheikh Salman, noted that hours before King Hamad brought in Gulf Co-operation Council (GCC) troops to restore order and crush dissent on 14 March 2011, the crown prince and opposition had agreed a seven-point plan that would have moved Bahrain towards a constitutional monarchy, )
(Sheikh Salman, said he was 'hopeful' that Senator John Kerry as US secretary of state would 'do more than his predecessor', Hillary Clinton)
(Sheikh Salman, said US policy needs to be more clear and direct, )
(Sheikh Salman, called for the release of 13 opposition leaders and human rights activists who have been sentenced to between five years and life in prison on evidence widely accepted as having been obtained under torture, ) ]
